title: Foldable devices
description: Foldables use flexible screens that can fold and unfold to seamlessly expand the available screen space as needed.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Device & environment
Get to know hardware and UI considerations that are key to designing for adaptive experiences.

Conditions and constraints to consider when adapting apps for foldable screens. 

Device context
Anticipated conditions
Considerations
Size
Small to medium: 4-6 inches (10-16cm) to 8-10 inches (20-25cm)
When folded, the device is comparable to a mobile phone. When unfolded, the screen space is comparable to a tablet.
Input modality
Touch; stylus
Maintain 48dp targets on interactive elements to support accessible touch interactions.
Viewing distance
12-20 inches (32-50cm)
Adaptive type can meet the needs of scaling content across various device postures.
Orientation
Landscape; portrait
Folding and unfolding can initiate a screen orientation change.
Ergonomics
Limited two-hand interaction; one-hand interaction
Some interactions, such as typing, can be slower on the unfolded screen.
Environment
Single-user experience; multi-device contexts
Consider the user's ecosystem of devices and how a foldable device offers a unique context for experiences such as content consumption.
Placement
Close proximity; distance-viewing
Adapting type scales can support the needs of scaling content across device sizes.
Postures
Postures are the screen configurations that foldable devices can take on, offering several different layout contexts for an app.

Folded

The folded posture has a front screen that uses similar proportions to a typical mobile phone. 

When designing for the folded screen posture, refer to general guidance for mobile devices throughout the site.

contentChunks.footer: Similar to regular phones in proportion, a folded posture has 1 front screen.
contentChunks.altText: Front screen displaying text message

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Unfolded

An unfolded posture refers to the opened screen, which is typically double the size of the front screen or the size of a small tablet. An unfolded posture can have landscape and portrait orientations.

In an unfolded posture, the device's folding hinge can be noticeable on some models. In the unique case of Microsoft's Surface Duo, the hinge divides the screen physically.

Unfolded landscape

Landscape mode applies when the longer screen edge is horizontal and the shorter edge is vertical.

contentChunks.footer: In an unfolded landscape, the longer edge is horizontal while the vertical edge is shorter.
contentChunks.altText: Unfolded device in landscape mode

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Unfolded portrait

Portrait mode applies when the longer screen edge is vertical and the shorter edge is horizontal.

contentChunks.footer: In an unfolded portrait, the longer edge is vertical while the shorter edge is horizontal.
contentChunks.altText: Unfolded device in portrait mode

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Tabletop

Tabletop describes a screen posture in which one half of the folding screen sits perpendicular to the other half. The tabletop posture resembles a laptop: one part of the screen is flat, as though sitting flat on a table, while the other half sits upright at roughly a 90-degree angle.

contentChunks.footer: Tabletop is a posture in which one part of the screen is flat and the other half is perpendicular, or halfway folded.
contentChunks.altText: Unfolded device in tabletop mode

contentChunks.htmlValue: Reachability

When the screen is unfolded, the top 25% of the screen is likely out of reach for most, unless the grip is adjusted. To accommodate device and hand sizes, limit the amount of interactions that are placed in the upper 25% of the screen. Additionally, avoid placing essential interactive elements too close to the bottom edge of the screen. Some users, particularly those with larger hands, might struggle to reach this area of the screen.

When users hold an opened device, their reach is likely limited. Specify interactions in a layout with these ergonomic regions in mind.

1. Users can reach this area by extending their fingers, which makes it slightly inconvenient for many to reach. 

2. Users can reach this area comfortably

3. Reaching this area is challenging when holding the device.

contentChunks.footer: Diagram of an unfolded device showing three zones for varying interaction considerations.
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of reachability areas with easiest in the middle, more challenging in the middle and very challenging on the bottom.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Limit interactions in the upper quarter of the screen. The top 25% of the screen can be hard to reach without changing one's grip.

contentChunks.footer: The top area of the screen (1) is difficult to reach when users hold a device with two hands.
contentChunks.altText: Screen image with top quarter highlighted

contentChunks.htmlValue: Placing critical and frequently used elements close to the screen's bottom edge and corners makes them harder to reach.

contentChunks.footer: Avoid positioning elements like FABs too close to the bottom corner of a screen. This makes them hard to reach, as larger devices will limit how far the thumb can reach towards the far corner, especially when using the device one-handed.
contentChunks.altText: FAB placed on bottom right screen corner

contentChunks.htmlValue: Center hinge

The center of the folding screen has a tactile difference due to the device hinge that enables folding. 

Avoid placing important information and actions along the center 48dp of an unfolded screen.

contentChunks.footer: Diagram of the central hinge on an unfolded screen.
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of screen with center hinge

contentChunks.htmlValue: Example of a center hinge in landscape mode. Avoid placing important interactive elements in this area.

contentChunks.footer: Diagram of a center hinge on a device in landscape mode.
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of screen with physical hinge

contentChunks.htmlValue:
There are two types of hinges on folded devices: 

  1. Seamless hinges are barely visible, although some users may feel a tactile difference on the screen surface
  2. Hinges that physically divide the device effectively into two screens

contentChunks.footer: Device with a seamless hinge
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of screen with seamless hinge

contentChunks.htmlValue: On devices with a physical hinge, designing the screen as two distinct halves allows a composition to work well across the seam and screens.

contentChunks.footer: Device with a physical hinge
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of screen with physical hinge

contentChunks.htmlValue: Example of a dialog positioned adjacent to a center hinge that divides the two halves of the screen.

contentChunks.altText: A dialog placed positioned adjacent to a center hinge.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Avoid placing key actions, such as dialog buttons, along the center hinge.

contentChunks.footer: Avoid placing key actions in line with a center hinge.
contentChunks.altText: Elements set in middle of screen

contentChunks.footer: Place key elements like dialogs on either side of the screen.
contentChunks.altText: Elements situated on both screen sides

contentChunks.footer: Avoid placing key actions in the middle of the screen.
contentChunks.altText: Elements set in middle of screen

contentChunks.htmlValue: Dividing the screen
When dividing the screen into composition areas, avoid placing important actions in the middle 48dp area of the screen. Compositions work best with 2 columns for layout.

Landscape

In a landscape orientation, place primary navigational components on the vertical edges of the screen (1) and separate content and elements into two columns (2).

contentChunks.footer: Content and elements separated into two columns: A navigation rail (1) provides an ergonomic way to navigate an experience, while content is divided into two columns that use the screen width (2).
contentChunks.altText: A list detail view using 2 columns

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Portrait

Use one column for portrait layouts. Horizontal space is limited in portrait mode, leaving little room to meaningfully implement two columns.

contentChunks.footer: Use a single column for a foldable app’s portrait layout
contentChunks.altText: 1 column set on foldable app in portrait layout

contentChunks.htmlValue: Use two columns for an unfolded portrait layout if content can fit within the narrow view without excessive distortion.

contentChunks.footer: Use two columns in a portrait layout only if content fits the narrower view
contentChunks.altText: 2-column layout with content

contentChunks.htmlValue: Complex list items can make it hard to comfortably view content across two compressed columns.

contentChunks.footer: Two columns may be too narrow for large blocks of text
contentChunks.altText: Example image of list items with a large amount of text

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Extend or combine windows

 When designing for foldable devices, there are two primary methods for managing the expanding and contracting screen space. 

When screen space is expanded because the device is unfolded, the larger canvas can be used for either extending an existing view or adding a separate, additional view. 

When unfolded, the first object in a list should open, unless an item is selected.

Extending a window

Extending means taking a typical mobile design and rearranging elements and content to make better use of the space. This can mean adding a second column of content or rearranging content areas. This method is akin to responsive design on the web. Some examples include:

  • Adding a second column of content 
  • Creating a more complex layout of photos
  • Introducing more negative space

contentChunks.footer: When compared to mobile layouts that typically use a single column (left), foldable devices (right) might use more than one column.
contentChunks.altText: side-by-side example of a mobile UI that uses one column for its content and an unfolded landscape mode device with content spread across two columns

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Combining windows

To adapt to a larger screen, two distinct views in a mobile UI can be used as a single view on on a larger device. Consider taking multiple screens from one flow and presenting them in a single view on a foldable device. 

Some examples include:

  • An inbox view alongside a single message view
  • Text message list view alongside a single conversation view
  • File browser view alongside an open folder
  • A musician's album information alongside music player controls

contentChunks.footer: On mobile (left) an app has two screens that can be combined into a single two column layout for an open foldable device (right).
contentChunks.altText: An example showing two different screens on the left and a combined screen on the right

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Scrolling

Depending on how your app extends or combines windows, the scroll behavior of the folded design may change in the unfolded design.

If you expand a window, you can decide whether the whole screen will scroll together or if each side (each column) scrolls independently.

If you choose to combine windows, each side of the screen will operate as independently scrollable areas.

contentChunks.footer: Two foldable devices: 1 (left) shows two independent scrolling columns and 2 (right) shows a single page of scrolling content.
contentChunks.altText: Example showing two columns of content that can scroll independently and two that scroll together

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Immersion
 

Immersion layouts create dedicated focus on a singular action or window, creating a distraction-free environment for a specific goal.

Some examples include

  • Playing a game
  • Watching a movie
  • Video calls 
  • Creative applications

contentChunks.footer: By keeping app layout focused on the video call, the experience doesn't compete for attention with other content.
contentChunks.altText: Example of a video call app with a row of buttons at the bottom of the screen

contentChunks.htmlValue: Navigation elements
On foldable devices, place navigational components close to edges of the screen, as they are easier to reach.

contentChunks.footer: Use a navigation rail component for primary navigation.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation rail set close to screen edge

contentChunks.htmlValue: Using navigation bars for primary navigation makes it hard for users to reach destinations in the middle of the screen.

contentChunks.footer: Bottom navigation bars are best used on mobile devices, while Navigation Rails are better suited for foldables and larger devices.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar set on bottom of foldable device

contentChunks.htmlValue:
An app may hide a navigation rail once it has reached a secondary destination, as long as you can show a back button to the primary destination.

Within a primary navigation, an app can use tabs or other navigation components for secondary levels of navigation or sorting and filtering actions.

contentChunks.footer: A secondary destination may hide a navigation rail when opened, so showing a back button helps return to the primary destination.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Secondary navigation

Top app bars

The app bar container is used to display and group components that help users perform primary actions, or take action on elements in the body container.

The app bar container can be combined with the navigation container.

contentChunks.footer: Using a top app bar can create a banding effect on the screen.
contentChunks.altText: Top app bar showing banding effect

contentChunks.htmlValue: Transient components

Dialogs

Place dialogs on either side of the screen, in order to avoid placing key interactions in the middle.

contentChunks.footer: Place dialogs on either side of the screen.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Multi-window dynamics

Foldables provide a larger surface area that’s optimized to display more than one app at a time. This extra space can be especially effective for multi-tasking or workflows that depend on comparison or management of information. By minimizing a user’s need to switch between apps on a single screen, productive, empowering, and more seamless user flows are possible.

In Android 12, users can create and review multiple windows in the new overview. Learn more about the Android 12 Recents screen.
Drag & drop

With the Android drag and drop framework, you can allow users to move data with a graphical drag and drop gesture. The gesture can traverse one view to another in the same app, or between one app and a different one when multi-window mode is enabled.

Although the framework is primarily designed for data movement, you can use it for other UI actions. For example, you can create an app that mixes colors when the user drags a color icon over another icon.

App continuity

When running on a foldable device, an app can transition from one screen to another automatically. After the transition, the app should resume in the same state and location, and the current task should continue seamlessly.

Being able to run multiple windows is one of the benefits of large screens. In the past, having two apps side by side was common in some devices. The technology has improved to the point where three or more apps can run on the screen at the same time, and also share content between themselves.

User needs

The ways that windows are created, arranged, and adjusted should feel straightforward for all users and across any screen size. 

Methods for seamless window management include:

  • Apply smooth transitions as described in motion guidance
  • Ensure that users can create multiple windows easily and move between them as needed
  • Keep mental models and interaction patterns simple so that users aren’t required to think about which mode is appropriate for each task
  • Design and implement window dynamics consistently across variations in foldable hardware, including those with a physical, visible hinge

contentChunks.footer: Users typically use multiple windows to display and use apps side-by-side. For example, a photo app and an inbox.
contentChunks.altText: Side-by-side windows displaying apps

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Window creation and behavior

Android provides several ways for users to create a multi-window view.

Taskbar

With Android 12, the taskbar provides a launching point for pinned and suggested apps to easily become a separate window. To create a new window, a user selects and drags an app from the taskbar and moves the app icon to indicate where the new window should be displayed.

contentChunks.footer: The taskbar can be used as a starting point for creating multiple windows.
contentChunks.altText: Taskbar with shortcut icons displayed across the bottom of the screen.

contentChunks.footer: Dragging an app from the taskbar towards one side of a screen creates a split-window view.
contentChunks.altText: Dragging an icon from the taskbar to the right side of the screen to open a split-window

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Context menu

Users can also create multiple windows through the overview by the app context menu.

contentChunks.footer: After the first app is pinned to the screen's edge using the context menu, tapping a second app from the overview will trigger the split screen
contentChunks.altText: 6 open windows featuring various apps

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Adjusting window sizes

By default multiple windows are created as a 50/50 side-by-side split. Multiple windows are a temporary arrangement. When the handle is dragged to the edge of a screen, the window being reduced will close, exiting multi-window view.

The windows can be adjusted further to 1:3 or 2:3 proportions. These ratios provide a primary and secondary window dynamic, offering greater flexibility and allowing focus on one application as needed. 

The screen handle can be dragged and released to create the desired window ratio. The handle automatically adjusts to the closest snap point.

The handle can also be used to close one window, which will exit out of the multiple window view.

contentChunks.footer: Resizing and closing a multi-window using the split screen handle
contentChunks.altText: A handle is dragged to the right, changing the window size, then dragging the handle to the screen's edge to make the left window full-screen.

contentChunks.footer: Vertical 50/50 split
contentChunks.altText: Two apps side-by-side in split-screen view

contentChunks.footer: Horizontal 50/50 split
contentChunks.altText: Two apps in horizontal split-screen, one above the other.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Apps can be sized to fill a third of the available window space. Due to the reduced surface area and squeeze applied to the layout, ensure that apps can still provide a usable experience at this narrow width by avoiding complex operations while in this ratio.

contentChunks.footer: An app can be sized to fill a third of the available window space as long as it still provides a usable experience at this narrow width
contentChunks.altText: A split-screen view with one app utilizing a third of the screen and the other utilizing the remaining two-thirds.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Drag and drop

A drag and drop interaction on a foldable device is used to organize, edit, and apply actions for one or more elements at a time, making common user goals simpler and more efficient. Foldable devices provide an advantage for drag and drop actions as the additional screen or surface area can streamline the action and provide immediate feedback for where a dragged item can go.

Keep in mind that for larger screens, when the drag is controlled by a touchpad or a mouse with slower tracking, that it can be difficult to move an object across a large distance as the finger might reach the edge of the touchpad before the dragged item has reached its destination.

Android drag and drop framework

The Android drag and drop framework allows users to move data with a graphical drag and drop gesture. The gesture can traverse one view to another in the same app, or between one app and a different one when multi-window mode is enabled.

Although the framework is primarily designed for data movement, you can use it for other UI actions. For example, you can create an app that mixes colors when the user drags a color icon over another icon.

Coarse and fine targeting

The level of indication should generally rise with the intended reliance on the interaction for completing an action. For touch interactions, avoid positioning the dragged item where it can be blocked from view by the finger or hand.

Coarse targeting

The destination of a draggable item can be coarse or fine, depending on the app context. 

A drop into a coarse target typically results in the item appearing at the end of a series or block of content.

Fine targeting

By contrast, a drop interaction to a fine target provides feedback during the interaction that signals exactly where the drop will happen. 

For example, for messaging and writing documents, the cursor can be used to show where a dropped element will appear and with relative precision.

The cursor feedback responds to the movement of the image being dragged into place. These subtle indicators show where precisely the object will be dropped within the text.

Visual indicators

Visual indicators that show an element is draggable can be highly prominent or mostly hidden, depending on priority level. Indication methods are listed from most noticeable to least:

  1. A persistent affordance visible on an object, such as a drag handle that represents a visual grip 
  2. Explicit call-out in the surrounding context, such as labels
  3. Cues are visually hidden until a passive interaction (such as hover) or implication through context
  4. Fully hidden until drag action is initiated

Depending on the use case and flow, there may be times when raising the indication level is necessary, while at other times it may not be a primary interaction in the flow and a supporting and complementary indication is more appropriate.

Drop zones

 A drop zone is a consistent visual pattern that clarifies expectations and the type of interaction. Examples of drop zone patterns include:

  • Persistent zone: Footprint shown at rest, before any drag operations have begun. Used to inform that drag and drop is available, and can serve as a functional drop. Examples include a region on the page for uploading files that is present when loaded. 
  • Hotspots: Indications that appear when a drag is initiated, to help inform where a drop interaction can occur. This can be useful when there are multiple drop zones available, or when it’s helpful to indicate which portion of the screen will be impacted by the drop.
  • Pre-defined zone: Boundaries are shown when drag is initiated. Informs a pre-defined space as a container that the drop will fill. Examples include rearranging apps on a home screen, or showing where a reordered list item will be placed. 
  • Windows: Informs where a dragged item will replace part of the screen, such as for multi-window creation. By default this pattern is coplanar, resulting in a push on surrounding screen elements.

Dragging between apps

When an item is moved from one app into another, the interaction is affected by the dragged item’s MIME type and the drop zone. The majority of dragged elements fall into image or text types.

Dragging a single item

Single-item MIME typeDrag type appearance
imagestatic image thumbnail
videostatic image thumbnail
texttext block
applicationapplication icon
modelfile thumbnail (no preview)
fontfile thumbnail (no preview)

Accessibility

Key considerations for accessible drag and drop interactions include:

  • People who rely on keyboard navigation may not see a cursor change state to communicate that an item is draggable. Adding visual affordances like a grip, an icon, or elevation can be used to communicate this to the user.
  • Provide a consistent pattern for initiating drag or introduce a fallback alternative to help users move across multiple products and platforms. 
  • Aria roles, consistent keyboard controls, and screen reader support should indicate draggability and status throughout an interaction.
Opening, closing, and rotating the device
Folded portrait to open landscape

Motion is used to highlight new content revealed by a larger unfolded canvas.

The nav bars and details page are animated to call attention to them.

contentChunks.footer: Example of a mail app on a foldable device opening from a closed, portrait-mode posture into unfolded landscape posture.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Avoid pausing on the previous posture's layout after folding or unfolding. Instead, seamless transitions across postures take place simultaneously with folding and unfolding of the device.

contentChunks.footer: Avoid delays in initiating a layout transition.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Motion can be used to highlight important UI elements.
Continuity across postures can also be reinforced in the motion of a banner extended horizontally to make use of the larger screen width. A search bar might also behave similarly.
When folding into tabletop mode, hero elements like a video can expand to fill the top half of the screen. Supporting elements like media controls fill the bottom half of the screen.
Component transitions

Border enter and exit

This transition is used on components near the edge of the screen that exit or enter as layouts adapt.

  • Bottom navigation
  • Navigation rail
  • App bars
  • Sheets
  • Media controls

contentChunks.footer: A navigation bar transitions to a navigation rail as the screen expands.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Adding a panel

This transition is used to draw attention to a new panel revealed by a larger canvas.

contentChunks.footer: With the increase in screen size, a supporting panel enters the view from the side.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Peer transition: navigation

A peer transition between top level navigation items uses a shared y-axis transition. The details page slides up or down depending on the relative order of the selected list item.

contentChunks.footer: Elements on the y-axis transition in sync to reinforce subtle shifts in content states.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Parent-child navigation: lists

A parent child transition for nested lists uses a shared x-axis transition.

contentChunks.footer: A list item transitions to a detail view.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Parent-child navigation: cards

Cards use a container transform for parent child transitions.

contentChunks.footer: A card container scales from a small element to an immersive view.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Dialog entrance

Use motion to draw attention to the new content revealed in the dialog box. 

The vertical motion of the text and buttons add detail to the dialog box expansion.

contentChunks.footer: A dialog can appear with a phased vertical animation.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Don’t expand dialog boxes uniformly from the center. The content should never fade in and overlap or move in opposing directions while the dialog box expands.

contentChunks.footer: Avoid introducing dialogs with uniform scaling.
